name: id
comment: Unique identified for the record

name: parent_id
comment: Parent ID. ID of the parent variable if this variable has any parent.

name: client_id
comment: Client ID. Your QuantiModo client id can be obtained by creating an app at https://builder.quantimo.do (type: string)

name: user_id
comment: Numeric User ID

name: variable_id
comment: Variable ID. ID of variable. Ex: 13 (type: integer)

name: default_unit_id
comment: Default Unit ID. ID of unit to use for this variable.

name: minimum_allowed_value
comment: Minimum Allowed Value. Minimum reasonable value for this variable (uses default unit). User-Defined Variable Setting: The minimum allowed value a single measurement. While you can record a value below this minimum, it will be excluded from the correlation analysis. Unit: User-specified or common (type: number)

name: maximum_allowed_value
comment: Maximum Allowed Value. Maximum reasonable value for this variable (uses default unit). User-Defined Variable Setting: The maximum allowed value a single measurement. While you can record a value above this maximum, it will be excluded from the correlation analysis.  Unit: User-specified or common. (type: number)

name: filling_value
comment: Filling Value. Value for replacing null measurements. User-Defined Variable Setting: When it comes to analysis to determine the effects of this variable, knowing when it did not occur is as important as knowing when it did occur. For example, if you are tracking a medication, it is important to know when you did not take it, but you do not have to log zero values for all the days when you have not taken it. Hence, you can specify a filling value (typically 0) to insert whenever data is missing.  Unit: User-specified or common. (type: number)

name: join_with
comment: Join With. The Variable this Variable should be joined with. If the variable is joined with some other variable then it is not shown to user in the list of variables. Duplicate variables. If the variable is joined with some other variable then it is not shown to user in the list of variables (type: integer)

name: onset_delay
comment: Onset Delay. How long it takes for a measurement in this variable to take effect. The amount of time in seconds that elapses after the predictor/stimulus event before the outcome as perceived by a self-tracker is known as the onset delay. For example, the onset delay between the time a person takes an aspirin (predictor/stimulus event) and the time a person perceives a change in their headache severity (outcome) is approximately 30 minutes. (type: string)

name: duration_of_action
comment: Duration of Action. Estimated duration of time following the onset delay in which a stimulus produces a perceivable effect. The amount of time over which a predictor/stimulus event can exert an observable influence on an outcome variable value. For instance, aspirin (stimulus/predictor) typically decreases headache severity for approximately four hours (duration of action) following the onset delay. Unit: Seconds (type: string)

name: variable_category_id
comment: Variable Category ID. ID of variable category. Ex: 13 (type: integer)

name: public
comment: Public. Is variable public. Should this variable show up in automcomplete searches for users who do not already have measurements for it? (type: boolean)

name: cause_only
comment: Cause Only. A value of 1 indicates that this variable is generally a cause in a causal relationship.  An example of a causeOnly variable would be a variable such as Cloud Cover which would generally not be influenced by the behaviour of the user. User-Defined Variable Setting: True indicates that this variable is generally a cause in a causal relationship.  An example of a causeOnly variable would be a variable such as Cloud Cover which would generally not be influenced by the behaviour of the user (type: boolean)

name: filling_type
comment: Filling Type. 0 -> No filling, 1 -> Use filling-value. User-Defined Variable Setting: When it comes to analysis to determine the effects of this variable, knowing when it did not occur is as important as knowing when it did occur. For example, if you are tracking a medication, it is important to know when you did not take it, but you do not have to log zero values for all the days when you have not taken it. Hence, you can specify a filling value (typically 0) to insert whenever data is missing. (type: string)

name: number_of_measurements
comment:
Number of Raw Measurements. Number of measurements. 
Calculation formula: 
    update user_variables uv 
    join measurements m on uv.id = m.user_variable_id 
    set uv.number_of_measurements = COUNT(measurements.id). Filter variables by the total number of measurements that they have. This could be used of you want to filter or sort by popularity. (type: string)

name: number_of_processed_daily_measurements
comment: Number of Processed Daily Measurements. Number of processed measurements. Number of processed measurements (type: integer)

name: measurements_at_last_analysis
comment: Measurements at Last Analysis. Number of measurements at last analysis. Number of measurements at last analysis (type: integer)

name: last_unit_id
comment: Last Unit ID. ID of last Unit.

name: last_original_unit_id
comment: Last Original Unit ID. ID of last original Unit.

name: last_value
comment: Last Value. Calculated Statistic: Last measurement value in the common unit or user unit if different. Unit: User-specified or common. (type: number)

name: last_original_value
comment: Last Original Value. Last original value which is stored.

name: number_of_correlations
comment: Number of Correlations. Number of correlations for this variable. Number of correlations for this variable (type: integer)

name: status
comment: Status. ex. OK or ERROR (type: string)

name: standard_deviation
comment: Standard deviation. Standard deviation Ex: 0.46483219855434 (type: number)

name: variance
comment: Variance. Statistic: Ex: 115947037.40816 (type: number)

name: minimum_recorded_value
comment: Minimum Recorded Value. Minimum recorded value of this variable. Minimum recorded value of this variable. Unit: User-specified or common. (type: number)

name: maximum_recorded_value
comment: Maximum Recorded Value. Maximum recorded value of this variable. Calculated Statistic: Ex: 1. Unit: User-specified or common. (type: number)

name: mean
comment: Mean. Mean. Unit: User-specified or common. (type: number)

name: median
comment: Median. Median (type: number)

name: most_common_original_unit_id
comment: Most Common Original Unit ID. Most common Unit ID. Ex: 23 (type: integer)

name: most_common_value
comment: Most common value. Calculated Statistic: Most common value. Unit: User-specified or common. (type: number)

name: number_of_unique_daily_values
comment: Number of unique daily values. Number of unique daily values (type: number)

name: number_of_unique_values
comment: Number of unique values. Ex: 1 (type: integer)

name: number_of_changes
comment: Number of changes. Number of changes (type: integer)

name: skewness
comment: Skewness. Skewness (type: number)

name: kurtosis
comment: Kurtosis. Kurtosis (type: number)

name: latitude
comment: Latitude. Unit: User-specified or common. (type: number)

name: longitude
comment: Longitude. Longitude (type: number)

name: location
comment: Location. Location (type: string)

name: created_at
comment: Time at which the User Variable was Created At. When the record was first created. Use UTC ISO 8601 YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss datetime format. Time zone should be UTC and not local. (type: string)  in the format YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS in the UTC timezone.

name: updated_at
comment: Time at which the User Variable was Updated At. When the record was last updated. Use UTC ISO 8601 YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss datetime format. Time zone should be UTC and not local. (type: string)  in the format YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS in the UTC timezone.

name: outcome
comment: Outcome. Outcome variables (those with `outcome` == 1) are variables for which a human would generally want to identify the influencing factors.  These include symptoms of illness, physique, mood, cognitive performance, etc.  Generally correlation calculations are only performed on outcome variables. User-Defined Variable Setting: True for variables for which a human would generally want to identify the influencing factors. These include symptoms of illness, physique, mood, cognitive performance, etc.  Generally correlation calculations are only performed on outcome variables (type: boolean)

name: data_sources_count
comment: Data Sources Count. Array of connector or client measurement data source names as key and number of measurements as value.

name: earliest_source_time
comment: Earliest source time. Earliest source time (type: integer)

name: latest_source_time
comment: Latest source time. Latest source time. Format: Unix-time epoch seconds. (type: integer)

name: earliest_filling_time
comment: Earliest filling time. Earliest filling time (type: integer)

name: latest_filling_time
comment: Latest filling time. Latest filling time (type: integer)

name: last_processed_daily_value
comment: Last Processed Daily Value. Last value for user after daily aggregation and filling. Calculated Statistic: Ex: 500. Unit: User-specified or common. (type: number)

name: outcome_of_interest
comment: Outcome of Interest. Do you want to receive updates on newly discovered factors influencing this variable? (type: boolean)

name: predictor_of_interest
comment: Predictor of Interest. Ex: 0 (type: integer)

name: experiment_start_time
comment: Experiment Start Time. User-Defined Variable Setting: Earliest measurement time to be used in analysis. Format: UTC ISO 8601 YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss. (type: string)

name: experiment_end_time
comment: Experiment End Time. User-Defined Variable Setting: Latest measurement time to be used in analysis. Format: UTC ISO 8601 YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss. (type: string)

name: description
comment: Description. Valence indicates what type of buttons should be used when recording measurements for this variable. positive - Face buttons with the happiest face equating to a 5/5 rating where higher is better like Overall Mood. negative - Face buttons with happiest face equating to a 1/5 rating where lower is better like Headache Severity. numeric - Just 1 to 5 numeric buttons for neutral variables.  (type: string)

name: alias
comment: Alias. User-Defined Variable Setting:  Alternative display name (type: string)

name: deleted_at
comment: Time at which the User Variable was Deleted At.  in the format YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS in the UTC timezone.

name: second_to_last_value
comment: Second to Last Value. Calculated Statistic: Ex: 250. Unit: User-specified or common. (type: number)

name: third_to_last_value
comment: Third to Last Value. Calculated Statistic: Ex: 250. Unit: User-specified or common. (type: number)

name: number_of_user_correlations_as_effect
comment: Number of User Correlations as Effect. Number of user correlations for which this variable is the effect variable. Ex: 29014 (type: integer)

name: number_of_user_correlations_as_cause
comment: Number of User Correlations as Cause. Number of user correlations for which this variable is the cause variable. Ex: 115 (type: integer)

name: combination_operation
comment: Combination Operation. How to combine values of this variable (for instance, to see a summary of the values over a month) SUM or MEAN. User-Defined Variable Setting: How to aggregate measurements over time. SUM should be used for things like minutes of exercise.  If you use MEAN for exercise, then a person might exercise more minutes in one day but add separate measurements that were smaller.  So when we are doing correlational analysis, we would think that the person exercised less that day even though they exercised more.  Conversely, we must use MEAN for things such as ratings which cannot be SUMMED. (type: string)

name: share_user_measurements
comment: Share User Measurements. Should data for this variable be publicly available?. Would you like to make your measurements publicly visible? (type: boolean)

name: informational_url
comment: Informational Url. Wikipedia url. Ex: https://google.com (type: string)

name: most_common_connector_id
comment: Most Common Connector ID. Ex: 51 (type: integer)

name: valence
comment: Valence. Valence indicates what type of buttons should be used when recording measurements for this variable. positive - Face buttons with the happiest face equating to a 5/5 rating where higher is better like Overall Mood. negative - Face buttons with happiest face equating to a 1/5 rating where lower is better like Headache Severity. numeric - Just 1 to 5 numeric buttons for neutral variables.  (type: string)

name: wikipedia_title
comment: Wikipedia Title. User-Defined Variable Setting: You can help to improve the studies by pasting the title of the most appropriate Wikipedia article for this variable (type: string)

name: number_of_tracking_reminders
comment: Number of Tracking Reminders. Ex: 1 (type: integer)

name: number_of_raw_measurements_with_tags_joins_children
comment: Number of Raw Measurements With Tags Joins Children.

name: most_common_source_name
comment: Most Common Source Name.

name: optimal_value_message
comment: Optimal Value Message. Description of relationship with variable with strongest relationship for user or population (type: string)

name: best_cause_variable_id
comment: Best Cause Variable ID.

name: best_effect_variable_id
comment: Best Effect Variable ID.

name: best_user_correlation
comment: Best User Correlation.

name: user_maximum_allowed_daily_value
comment: User Maximum Allowed Daily Value.

name: user_minimum_allowed_daily_value
comment: User Minimum Allowed Daily Value.

name: user_minimum_allowed_non_zero_value
comment: User Minimum Allowed Non Zero Value.

name: minimum_allowed_seconds_between_measurements
comment: Minimum Allowed Seconds Between Measurements.

name: average_seconds_between_measurements
comment: Average Seconds Between Measurements.

name: median_seconds_between_measurements
comment: Median Seconds Between Measurements.

name: last_correlated_at
comment: Time at which the User Variable was Last Correlated At.  in the format YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS in the UTC timezone.

name: number_of_measurements_with_tags_at_last_correlation
comment: Number of Measurements With Tags at Last Correlation.

name: analysis_settings_modified_at
comment: Time at which the User Variable was Analysis Settings Modified At.  in the format YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS in the UTC timezone.

name: newest_data_at
comment: Time at which the User Variable was Newest Data At.  in the format YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS in the UTC timezone.

name: analysis_requested_at
comment: Time at which the User Variable was Analysis Requested At.  in the format YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS in the UTC timezone.

name: reason_for_analysis
comment: Reason for Analysis.

name: analysis_started_at
comment: Time at which the User Variable was Analysis Started At.  in the format YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS in the UTC timezone.

name: analysis_ended_at
comment: Time at which the User Variable was Analysis Ended At.  in the format YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS in the UTC timezone.

name: user_error_message
comment: User Error Message.

name: internal_error_message
comment: Internal Error Message.

name: earliest_source_measurement_start_at
comment: Time at which the User Variable was Earliest Source Measurement Start At.  in the format YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS in the UTC timezone.

name: latest_source_measurement_start_at
comment: Time at which the User Variable was Latest Source Measurement Start At.  in the format YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS in the UTC timezone.

name: latest_tagged_measurement_start_at
comment: Time at which the User Variable was Latest Tagged Measurement Start At.  in the format YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS in the UTC timezone.

name: earliest_tagged_measurement_start_at
comment: Time at which the User Variable was Earliest Tagged Measurement Start At.  in the format YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS in the UTC timezone.

name: latest_non_tagged_measurement_start_at
comment: Time at which the User Variable was Latest Non Tagged Measurement Start At.  in the format YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS in the UTC timezone.

name: earliest_non_tagged_measurement_start_at
comment: Time at which the User Variable was Earliest Non Tagged Measurement Start At.  in the format YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS in the UTC timezone.

name: wp_post_id
comment: Wp Post ID.

name: number_of_soft_deleted_measurements
comment:
Number of Soft Deleted Measurements. Formula: update user_variables v 
                inner join (
                    select measurements.user_variable_id, count(measurements.id) as number_of_soft_deleted_measurements 
                    from measurements
                    where measurements.deleted_at is not null
                    group by measurements.user_variable_id
                    ) m on v.id = m.user_variable_id
                set v.number_of_soft_deleted_measurements = m.number_of_soft_deleted_measurements
            .

name: charts
comment: Charts visualizing User Variable data.

name: best_user_correlation_id
comment: Best User Correlation ID.
